awd_abstract_narration:
This study expands scientific understanding of how an increase in uncertainty affects youth well-being. In a community in which some youth experience uncertainty and others do not, there is an opportunity to analyze whether, how, and to what extent changes in uncertainty affect youth. The findings from this study will inform discussions at the federal, state, and local levels about ways to increase well-being among youth, who face varying levels of uncertainty. 

This study will use multiple waves of representative California statewide data collected via the California Health Interview Survey from 2007-2016 (n=238,000), with subsequent years added as they are released. The project will estimate the impact of uncertainty by comparing youth who are and are not subject to uncertainty. It will follow both groups of youth longitudinally. Study outcomes include employment status, educational enrollment and attainment, and various measures of physical and psychological well-being. In addition, the project will examine spillover effects to the broader community. To further analyze findings, the project will produce an original longitudinal survey and in-depth interview study of 502 young people from the community in California. The project will compare key outcomes of these youth over the period between 2014 and 2020, thus allowing causal inferences regarding the impact of earlier events on later outcomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This study expanded our scientific understanding of how a change in uncertainty about the future (or, a change in precarity) affects the wellbeing of youth and young adults. We examine a community in which some youth experienced reductions to precarity, while others did not. This provided an opportunity to analyze whether, how, and to what extent changes in precarity affected youth and to what extent these changes were associated with reductions or enhancements in social inequality among youth. 

This study used multiple waves of representative California data from the California Health Interview Survey (CHIS) from 2007-2019, as well as representative U.S. data from  the American Community Survey (ACS). The project estimated the impact of precarity by comparing youths’ employment status, educational enrollment and attainment, poverty, and various measures of physical and psychological wellbeing. We also analyzed spillover effects onto those linked to impacted community members, i.e. children, using the CHIS, as well as birth records data from Vital Statistics.

Results from our statistical analyses suggest an association between reductions in precarity and increased mobility, as well as improved health and wellbeing, for youth who experience reductions in precarity, relative to those youth whose futures remained precarious. Our results also suggested a spillover association between reductions in precarity and improved health for children of impacted young adults, relative to children of parents who continued to face precarious futures.

To further analyze findings and better understand mechanisms, the project also produced original longitudinal survey and in-depth interview study originating with approximately 500 young people from California. The project compared key outcomes of these youth over the period between 2014 and 2019, thus allowing a closer identification of the mechanisms through which reductions in precarity may influence direct and spillover socioeconomic and health outcomes.

The findings from this study informed discussions at the federal, state, and local levels about ways to reduce inequality among youth. For example, the results were presented in multiple outlets (e.g. peer-reviewed articles, research briefs, opinion editorials, etc.), as well as to policymakers, advocates, and other stakeholders working to better serve youth in the community. 

 


Last Modified: 10/27/2022
Modified by: Caitlin Patler
